description: From Middle English afterclap, afterclappe, equivalent to after- +‎ clap. Compare Low German achterklap (“afterclap”).

entries.meaning: (archaic) An additional adverse event that occurs unexpectedly after an earlier one was thought to be over and done with.
examples: […]  immediatly after the Vniuersall deluge, Nimrod  […]  perswaded the people to secure themselues from the like after-claps, by building some stupendious Edifice, which might resist the fury of a second deluge.

entries.meaning: (archaic) An unfavourable turn of events following a favourable situation; an eventuality for which one ought to be prepared.
examples: Synonyms: calamity, disaster, peril, reversal, setback

entries.meaning: The consequence (often, but not always, adverse) of an action or event.
A phenomenon occurring after a similar earlier one; a later manifestation of something.
A sound that follows another, especially a loud noise, such as thunder.
A symptom of an illness, especially one that appears after the initial onset; an illness or symptom caused by exposure to a substance, an injury, etc.
(uncountable, medicine, obsolete) Urethral discharge as a symptom of gonorrhea.
(obsolete) A change or attempted change to an agreement after it has been entered into; an additional charge (especially one over and above the previously agreed-upon price).
examples: […]  he produced my Accompt in his Book, and very generously crossed it out, but I desired a Receipt to prevent any After-claps, which he readily granted, and then I very lovingly took my Leave of him.

entries.meaning: (humorous) A child born after the one that was intended to be the last.
examples: […]  there are only two girls. No after claps, like my sister Gresham’s little ‘Teddy;’  […]

entries.meaning: (slang, obsolete) A sweet food, drink, or tobacco product consumed at the end of a meal.

description: From Afrikaans agterklap < agter (“rear, after”) + klap (“flap”).

entries.meaning: (South Africa, historical) A canvas curtain or tailboard at the rear of a covered wagon.
